cons: The 2 coworkers acted as high school bullies, the boss was already on coworkers' "side" and I couldn't even defend myself against the lies. Drug tests were not reported accurately depending on whether they liked the client. After administering a drug test, I was told I was not reading it right when I know if I saw a line or not. I could keep going on, such as they were manipulative and conniving while smiling in one's face.

pros: They love to use all their policies in a way they serves them that day or situation. When you think you’re doing everything just right, you get notified you are NOT. But I know for facts multiple situations have occurred to know this, that the company and CYA’ing is the absolute most important as well as always their first go to! REGARDLESS OF HOW IT HORRIBLY AFFECTS THE CLIENT!
cons:
See above, please and thank you!
They pay pretty well, however, I can’t afford to pay premiums for the health insurance benefits, and they will load you up with so much work and responsibilities that you’ll say you need a raise!

job_title: Behavioral Health Technician in Jefferson City, MO
pros: The job is very fulfilling if you have a desire to work in mental health care and fight back against the addiction taking over our society.
cons: They are not picky about who they hire, so if you think this sounds like a good job for you, make sure your heart is in the work. You will be surrounded by coworkers who don't care at all about the job and just want a check. This IS healthcare and negligence here puts you, the clients, and the entire company at risk! But nothing ever happens because they're always understaffed and don't want to lose any employees willing to accept a position. You will end up working full-time hours even if you are "part-time" and you're expected to do so without complaint.

review_title: Loved being a part of the community

job_title: Counselor in Saint Louis, MO

job_title: Associate Counselor in Quincy, IL
pros:
-Same-level colleagues are wonderful and helpful
-You are exposed to different treatment modalities
-Providing support to the SUD population is rewarding
-No on call rotation
cons:
-Regular supervision is non-existent
-The population (adults with SUD) is highly unreliable when it comes to meeting with you and frequently do not show up. You will be reprimanded for missing that billing even when there's no other option
-If you have a chronic illness that takes any of your time or attention from the job, expect to be fired
-Management will talk down to you regardless of who you are, your experience, or what your concerns are
-If you don't fit in with management, you won't be there long
-Inadequate training for documentation, assessment, and evidence-based treatment
-You will share an office with at least 5 other people in a relatively small room with counter tops instead of desks

job_title: Maintenance Worker in Kansas City, MO
pros: Some good coworkers, and you get a paycheck. Client's were decent and enjoyed working with them and helping them.
cons: Job was sold as switching out light switch and outlet cover plates, light duties, maintenance and repairs. Actually, they want a professional drywall contractor, a professional painter, professional plumber and staff that is wholly subservient. There's no overtime like they say, if you get called in on your days off they will make you come in late or leave early on your work days. You should enjoy using a 3" or 4" roller and a gallon of paint while on your knees painting the parking lot lines. in 90 + weather for hours at a time, If you recommend a striping device they will turn it down. Management has high opinions of themselves but not of their staff. Unprofessional workplace with negative communications and no structure. Complaints to proper resources are denounced. Many good people at the company resigned because of the way they were treated and found other jobs. Do your due diligence on the company to research it better. If you enjoy all the latter, then by all means apply. But you'd be most likely better off at just about any other workplace in America.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Plenty of opportunity to work with clients who need assistance.
cons: This company is the epitome of the ivory tower and does not listen to, or support, front line employees. Their goal is to make money, each and every decision made is for this purpose, maximizing profit. This is okay if you know this and accept it, holding on to the belief that they are focused on clients or employees will bring frustration.

Supervisors really care about you and the clients. They are also personable and if you have a problem you can talk to them

Schedule is also flexible which means if you have a doctors appointment in middle of day it’s not an issue and you can just plan around it
cons: Nonprofit burnout is real. There’s a lot of high risk clients and not enough competent trained staff.

job_title: Case Manager in Saint Louis, MO

The main objective of the management here is to make sure that the company is making money off of clients and insurance companies. Not to mention that the clinical staff is deserving of a much higher paid salary. Could go on for hours about how unprofessional this company is. Avoid working here if possible.

review_title: Take your time and ask questions, get to know who you will be reporting to, do not relocate at your own expense.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: They pay well, benefits are moderate to good.  The agency recieves funds from a tax to citizens, therefore some of the expectations that state and federally funded agencies have are not as stringent.  They are expanding rapidly with this tax money, and have an airplane and other perks for upper managment.
cons: I knew of several coworkers who had been fired and then offered another position in the agency.    The staff who reported to these folks were told of the upcoming firing before the person to be let go.  I observed personnel being managed by scarcasm, slamming doors, raised voices and throwing things.

review_title: The company had a great mission statement, but not enough good employees to back it up.
job_title: Rehabilitation Technician and Associate Counselor in Kirksville, MO
pros: Good people with good intentions
cons: There is no appropriate consequence for employees who do not do their jobs well. Some employees simply are still employed because of seniority. They only do just enough to get by and that is not enough to make this company a quality company. Also, too much emphasis is put on billing, not on patient care. It seems that the company is more geared towards business rather than the general betterment of people's lives. There needs to be more reform in this company and a reevaluation of its employees.  Better training and supervision is needed.

job_title: Counselor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Other counselors, case workers, techs, and clinical staff are in it to win it for those in need of our help. The team can really come together and make miracles happen. People walk out of the door new men and women.
cons: Management, Administration, and the Powers that be just cannot keep their hands off what is already working well. They lack concern for the client centered approach and are more interested in the bottom dollar. Just an FYI,they do have quotas! They operate more like a fortune 500 rather than a non-profit. They're becoming very top heavy.

job_title: Manager in Hannibal, MO
pros: EXCellent mission to serve those who need it most.

Staff are overlooked for their ideas and then those ideas are presented by the VP as are own. CEO is afraid to rock the point since he trained her and does not step up, to help employees when asked for assistance.

job_title: Client Services in Little Rock, AR

review_title: Come for the pay, stay for the experience

job_title: Community Support Specialist in Kirksville, MO
pros:
Great experience in psychology, mental health, healthcare, and social sciences. Challenging work!

It is very fulfilling to teach people life skills that will improve their situation and ultimately empower them to build healthy relationships and achieve independence.
cons:
Supervisors should show trust and respect, offer support and council without belittling, and recognize that applying too much force does not build, it breaks. 

A leader should be kind but not rude and bold but not bully.  An employee should feel like they can come to you without the risk of an accusation or reprimand.

review_title: Good company. Good management. Pay is unfair.

review_title: A terrible company to work for! Horrible management and not enough follow through with the policies of the company.
